metadata.title: Clinical and Research Reports of Patients with Lung Cancer Amid the COVID-19 Pandemic in China

affiliation.institution: Huazhong University of Science and Technology
The Second Clinical Medicine College of Jinan University

abstract.text: authors contributed equally to this work.

Background: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak throughout the world has affected billions of people in many way putting a huge burden on the healthcare system. The ongoing outbreak of this respiratory disease has posed critical challenges for the public health, research, and medical communities around the world. This study aimed to examine the impact of COVID-19 pandemic on patients with lung cancer in China.

We collected data on 397 inpatients from a single center during 4 weeks of the epidemic time (2020 group), and that of 2504 inpatients during the same period (4 weeks) in last 5 years (2015-2019 group). A questionnaire was used to investigate medical demands among 803 patients with lung cancer at 65 hospitals from 20 provinces in China during the epidemic. We evaluate the incidence data of in Guangdong to analyze the tendency of the pandemic and compared it with inpatient data.

Results: The number of hospitalizations and lung cancer-related surgeries had steadily increased in 2015-2019 but reduced by an average of 26.72% (133.8) and 57.18% (45.4) in 2020. The hospital capacity decreased by 28.00% (35 inpatient beds) during the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic period. The epidemic caused a greater impact on medical work related to lung cancer after the Chinese New Year holiday. Patients were most concerned about longer waiting time for outpatient services, inpatient beds, physical examinations, or surgeries (406; 50.56%), the possibility of infection with the novel coronavirus (359; 44.71%), difficulties in getting to a hospital due to transportation outages (279; 34.74%). Patients in stage I and II showed less fear about disease progression (14, 18.18%; 4, 14.81%), lower proportions of delayed medical arrangement (15, 19.48%; 6, 22.22%) and less complain about complex treatment procedures (12, 15.58%, 5, 18.52%). Patients in high-infected area (345, 56.74%) complained more frequently about longer booking periods than in low-infected area (61, 31.28%).

Conclusion: Treatment of patients with lung cancer has been affected by the epidemic to some extent. We provide suggestions on both clinical diagnosis and treatment strategies of lung cancer to optimize the process regarding to the currently urgent circumstances. The demand for medical support among patients with lung cancer or other life-threatening diseases should be given sufficient attention, especially during the current COVID-19 outbreak.

body_text.text: Two months ago, a novel coronavirus (nCOV) appeared in China and spread across whole country causing tens of thousands of infections and thousands of deaths. 1 Its basic reproduction number (R0) ranged from 2 to 3.58 indicating its potential high infectiousness. 2, 3 The World Health Organization (WHO) on March 11 declared COVID-19 a pandemic. 4 Whereas 80,991 laboratory-confirmed cases had been identified in China as of March 13, 2020, a total of 51,767 cases had been confirmed in 122 other countries or territories. 5 We must realize that the pandemic threatens the survival of 7.8 billion people on the planet.

Cancer, as one of the leading causes of cancer death worldwide, had approximately 4292,000 new cancer cases per year in China. 6 Recent published data revealed 1.3% of COVID-19 infectors suffered from a variety of cancer simultaneously. 7 Lung cancer among all types, is the malignancy with highest morbidity and mortality worldwide. 8 Patients with lung cancer may also be immunocompromised having them be vulnerable to In addition, older patients with comorbidities are at increased risk of death. 9 Delayed treatment, especially for patients in advanced stages of the disease may lead to serious consequences. The sudden outbreak of COVID-19 has caused a huge consumption of medical supplies and requisition for medical staffs brings enormous effects on treatment of other life-threatening disease. By saying that, an intensive understanding of the real-world scenario for patient with lung cancer could help improve clinical management of patients to ensure the delivery of treatment in a time-effective manner.

We determined the vulnerable time for patients with lung cancer in Guangdong province during the COVID-19 outbreak was four weeks from January 18, 2020 to February 15, 2020. Guangdong province launched the First Level Response to Major Public Health Emergencies on January 23, 2020. The first COVID-19 case in Guangdong province was diagnosed on January 18, 2020, which was 6 days before the Chinese New Year holiday, while February 15, 2020 is the 16th day after the holiday. The same period from 2015-2019 was also 4 weeks peer years from the 6 days before the Chinese New Year. The Chinese New Year holiday usually lasts 7 days every year. Flowchart in supplemental appendix 1 summarizes the entire process.

We collected data of inpatients from a single center between January 18, 2020 and February 15, 2020 (the 2020 group) and those hospitalized from same period in 2015-2019 (2015-2019 group). Detailed information including their sex, age, tumor, node, or metastasis (TNM) stage (8th edition), pathological diagnosis, date of admission, date of discharge and the volume of surgery was retrospectively collected. Then, we analyzed the tendency of the epidemic in Guangdong, matched COVID-19 epidemic information with inpatient data, and identified the time point at which it started to interfere with daily work of the medical staff. Guangdong province's epidemic data can be accessed at the official website of the Health Commission of Guangdong Province. 10 This study was approved by the Hospital's Research Ethics Committee.

The survey was conducted on patients with lung cancer in February 2020 at 65 hospitals in 20 provinces nationwide using a self-administered questionnaire. All patients received the questionnaire survey at the hospital clinic. Through the interviews, we collected their age, sex, pathology, TNM stage, current plan of treatment, purpose of visiting, and difficulties in lung cancer diagnosis and treatment during the epidemic. Turning to the subgroup, we divided the people surveyed into a high-infected area group (n=608, 10 provinces) and a low-infected area group (n=195, 10 provinces/cities), according to the China national cumulative number of COVID-19 patients. 5 The provinces in the high-infected area group were considered the top 11 epidemic areas of the SARS-CoV-2. The primary outcome was the main difficulty that patients faced during the outbreak. All the patients provided written informed consent.

Continuous variables were expressed as median (interquartile range, IQR) and compared with the Mann-Whitney U test. Categorical variables were expressed as number (%) and comparisons between the 2015-2019 and 2020 groups were made by the Pearson's Chi-square test (χ 2 ). Cramer's V Coefficient was used to measure the degree of correlation between two categorical variables. Statistical analyses were performed with SPSS version 25.0 software (SPSS, Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). A two-sided α of less than 0·05 was considered statistically significant.

The clinical characteristics of lung cancer inpatients are presented in supplemental appendix 1. There were no significant differences (p>0.05) in age and gender between the two group. The groups showed significant differences in pathological diagnosis and distribution of TNM stages (p<0.05). The values of Cramer's V indicate a small magnitude of effect between groups and pathology (0.16) or TNM stage (0.10).

Since most rooms were occupied for quarantining and treating the COVID-19 patients, the hospital capacity for patients with lung cancer reduced by 35 beds (28.00%), from 125 in 2015-2019 to 90 in 2020. Throughout 2015 to 2019, the number of patients with pulmonary tumor and lung cancer related operations increased year by year, but declined sharply in 2020 (Fig 1a) , by an average of 26.72% (133.8) and 57.18% (45.4). The number of lung cancer patients who were hospitalized and those of daily admissions from the start of the epidemic to the end of the Chinese New Year holiday in 2020 was likely to remain almost the same as those during the corresponding period in 2015-2019. However, a notable difference between the two groups was observed after the holiday (Fig 1b) . This change was in line with the increasing trend in the number of new COVID-19 cases diagnosed in a single day in the province.

A total of 803 patients with pulmonary tumors from 65 hospitals in 20 provinces of China received our questionnaire forms. Most of them (530, 66.00%) came from the hospital in Guangdong and Hunan province, while the number of COVID-19 cases in these provinces ranked first and fourth, respectively except Hubei province in China. The clinical characteristics of the patients are presented in supplemental appendix 1, and the overall results of the questionnaire are shown in Figures 2 and 3a . More than a quarter of the participants (209, 26.03%) complained that they had to delay doctor's appointments and treatment or examination schedules due to the coronavirus outbreak. Moreover, 241 (30.01%) patients were worried about the disease progression or tumor relapse of tumors without proper management during the epidemic. The majority of interviewees (406, 50.56%) believed that it took much longer than previously hospitalization wait-time, outpatient services, or radiological examination. In addition, 359 patients concerned about possible infection with SARS-CoV-2, accounted for 44.71%. Patients also reported greater inconveniences in transportation (279, 34.74%) and more difficulties in having a doctor's appointment (128, 15.94%). A minority of participants (51, 6.35%) indicated that they had shortages of tumor-related medications.

Turning to the subgroup, there was a notable difference between high and low infected area groups about longer booking periods. (Figure 3b ). More lung cancer patients in high-infected area group (345, 56.74%) complained about longer booking periods than in low-infected area group (61, 31.28%). Beyond that, patients in stage III and IV seems face more difficulties than those in stage I and II (Figure 4a ). More than half of the patients in stage III expressed the concern about longer of waiting time (71, 60.17%). Patients in stage I and II showed less fear about disease progression (14, 18.18%; 4, 14.81%), lower proportions of delayed medical arrangement (15, 19 .48%; 6, 22.22%) and less complain about complex treatment procedures (12, 15.58%, 5, 18.52%).

We report a real-world predicament of patients with lung cancer amid the SARS-Cov-2 epidemic. Factors such as medicine, surgery, radiological examinations, and consultation of the patients were affected. The understandable medical demands of patients with lung cancer are being compromised by the severe epidemic. Being threatened by two extremely dangerous diseases at the same time, patients likely have to endure more psychological pressure than others. Over 30, 000 physicians and nurses around China have been to Hubei province providing medical support and non-health professionals were advised to stay at home due to the risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection. Therefore, the major problem for patients with cancer is the inability to receive necessary medical services.

In this study we found that in addition to the "a cliff-like-drop" in the number of hospitalizations and the amount of surgery, the clinical characteristics about pathology and TNM stage were also different from the same period in last 5 year. They may be related to the delay in routine medical examinations or treatment arrangements for some patients. The reduced number of inpatient admissions and surgeries was due to the fact that rooms previously used for patients with early-or advanced-stage lung cancer before the outbreak were repurposed to quarantine and treat patients with COVID-19 during the pandemic. Elective admissions for surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy and immunotherapy, and emergency admissions to manage toxicities of cancer related symptoms were also mainly influenced by the room occupied. In China, another factor influencing the admissions process was that every non-emergent patient and their accompany relatives have to be tested for SARS-CoV-2 nucleic acid 2 or 3 times before admission. This was an effective measure to prevent a COVID-19 outbreak in the hospital, but 2-3 days are required to receive the result. Moreover, patient's attitude towards daily medical treatment was more cautious during the COVID-19 pandemic. Traffic control and the risk of exposure in hospitals prevent people from going to hospitals, which is beneficial for epidemic control, but it can also be problematic for those with other diseases that need to be diagnosed and treated. In addition, the sudden COVID-19 outbreak has led to insufficient supplies of protective equipment and the reduction in the number of blood donors. Medical staff in different positions were recruited to support the diagnosis, treatment and prevention of COVID-19. Overall, the lack of medical resources makes medical staff more conservative in their daily work. Therefore, allocation of scarce resources in a pandemic should be based on maximizing health benefits. 11 At this time, a special guideline for the diagnosis, treatment and follow-up of lung cancer during the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic will help provide orderly conduct of daily medical work. 12 In addition, patient's subjective feelings should not be ignored, especially during crisis periods. According to our study, their most of their concerns during the epidemic include longer waiting time for outpatient services, inpatient beds, examinations, or surgeries (406, 50.56%). Others included possibility of being infected with the novel coronavirus (359, 44.71%) and difficulties in going to hospital due to transportation outages (279, 34.74%). In addition, 209 (26.03%) patients indicated that their treatment was delayed due to the current COVID-19 outbreak. Subgroup analysis suggested that patients in stage III and IV seems face more difficulties than those in stage I and II. That is understandable because locally advanced and advanced lung cancer patients with a higher tumor burden are elder and have shorter absent treatment windows period and worse prognosis than those in early stage. Some of them are immunocompromised, vulnerable to SARS-CoV-2. Besides, more patients with lung cancer in high-infected areas complained of longer appointment periods, which may be related to the mobilization of more resources in these areas to fight COVID-19. Long waiting periods along with delayed diagnosis and treatment may lead to the lung cancer progression and interfere with the best treatment outcomes.

European Society for Medical Oncology (ESMO) proposed managements for patients with lung cancer during the COVID-19 pandemic. 13 The guideline established priority groups for different patients with different stages and medical purposes. For every group, it sets out three priority levels (high, medium and low). In addition, the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) recommends developing a fair and consistent prioritization and allocation policy. 11 These documents should supplement and not supersede applicable local, regional or national allocation plans. 11 We herein provide supplementary suggestions on both clinical diagnosis and treatment strategies for lung cancer regarding to the urgent circumstances, based on our institutional implementation (Figure 4b ).

First, for those patients with ground-glass opacity (GGO), it's crucial to determine whether it's COVID-19 or lung tumor as they may share identical appearance at the beginning. Surgical indication under such circumstances should be holding tight and surveillance interval should be extended in consideration of its slow-growing tumor biology and possibility of benign disease. Second, for patients with locally advanced lung cancer and N2 positive status, which is high heterogeneous, neoadjuvant-targeted therapy was preliminary proven safe and efficient in patients harboring activating mutations in oncogenes such as epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK). 14, 15 Multiple ongoing clinical trials incorporating checkpoint inhibitors into neoadjuvant therapy for NSCLC had showed encouraging findings about high major pathologic response (MPR) rate. [16] [17] [18] Therefore, neoadjuvant targeted therapy or immunotherapy is considerable option when medical supply was limited and immediate surgery was not available. For patients with advanced disease, medical policy should allow outpatient to be provided prescription dose for longer times in case of repeated round trip for prescription. On the other hand, patients who should have returned for immunotherapy or chemotherapy could be bypassed to the local hospitals which beard less clinical burden of COVID-19. The safety and efficacy are similar for patients transitioning from nivolumab 3mg/kg Q2W to 480mg Q4W 19 or from pembrolizumab 2mg/kg Q3W to 400 mg Q6W. 20 Long dosing interval would decrease the frequency of visit to the hospital and has the potential to reduce SARS-Cov-2 exposure risk. Both immunotherapy and chemotherapy could notably influence the host immune system, which may interact with COVID-19 infection causing extra damage. Therefore, we should obviously stay vigilant for suspected infectors receiving antitumoral treatment in case of disease deterioration. Finally, for patients involved in ongoing trials before COVID-19 epidemic, delayed medication might influence the efficacy and meanwhile, violate the study protocol. Affiliated centers should unleash their local advantages to proceed treatment for those who took medication injection like immunotherapy or chemotherapy. Also, study nurses should keep close online follow-up of participants to ease up their anxiety.

COVID-19 seemed to be far away from oncologists, yet being human beings, all physicians and patients were in the same boat. Until now, over three thousand physicians were reported to be infected while working in their clinical practice even when they maintained vigilance for the disease. Considering its relative long latency period and lack of classic symptoms, it's definitely pivotal to reduce chance of those innocent patients getting infected on the road to fight against cancer. Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, solving immediate problems and preventing problems are two equally important responsibilities for every leader globally. 21 China's experience in epidemic prevention will help governors and medical staff in other countries to fight the COVID-19. In the fast-rising period of the epidemic, some medical problems might be temporarily suppressed or ignored due to the focus on SARS-CoV-2. However, as the epidemic continues, other medical problems will gradually be exposed, and lung cancer is one of them. This study provides a reference for how lung cancer or other life-threatening diseases during the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic has been managed.

Indeed, several limitations may hinder the findings from current study. Inadequate surveillance prevented us from identifying any influence on cancer patients' prognosis. Another limitation of current study is that the patients surveyed were mainly derived from Guangdong and Hunan provinces. Therefore, the results may not be sufficiently representative for other places. From January 18th to April 18th, only one inpatient (1/24) was found to have both lung cancer and COVID-19 in our center. He was a 57-year-old man with mild COVID-19 and advanced pulmonary adenocarcinoma. He used to receive treatment with epidermal growth factor receptor tyrosine kinase inhibitors, chemo-immunotherapy and chemotherapy. He had a fever as the initial and only symptom after he came back from Wuhan. As per the local policy, he underwent corona virus testing, was quarantined in our hospital, and then transferred to an infectious disease hospital for further treatment as soon as he tested positive. However, we could not determine the outcome due to the patient being transferred.

Despite these desperate times, we human as a community with a shared future for mankind, should stand together for not only coronavirus epidemic but also other critical illness and coordinate socioeconomic development. Enhanced humanistic care, unfold online consultation and cut down materials consumption achieving new balance between epidemic isolation and social development.

In summary, we used the hospital data from a single center and simultaneously collected data using a self-structured questionnaire at multiple centers to examine the impact of the COVID-19 outbreak on the diagnosis and treatment of patients with lung cancer. We provide suggestions on both clinical diagnosis and treatment strategies of lung cancer to optimize the process regarding to the currently urgent circumstances. The demand for medical support among patients with lung cancer or other life-threatening diseases should be given sufficient attention, especially during the current COVID-19 outbreak. Line: Cumulative number of lung cancer and COVID-19. Before the end of the traditional Chinese New Year holiday, the tendency of the number of cumulative inpatients with lung cancer is almost the same as the previous 5 years; however, a notable different was seen when the holiday was over.
